there is to be hostile action between Canada and tlie United States, there is a threat held out by their employers in Detroit that in a few days they will be told they cannot continue to have employment in Detroit unless they remove to the American side. And every time it comes up, the citizens of Windsor are concerned lest the result be that, instead of Windsor increasing as few other cities have-as it has been doing in the past few years-its progress may be retarded. Therefore, hon. gentlemen should not treat this question in any hasty or flippant way. It is a matter to be dealt with most soberly and with a great deal of caution. In view of the facts I have stated, I think every hon. gentleman should accede to the reasonable request that this should be sent to the committee, and there discussed soberly and carefully. Hon. gentlemen will notice that in the amendment which is proposed it is suggested that the information may be laid by any person before two justices of the peace of the county. Is that not pretty radical and pretty far-reaching ? Any person, perhaps some man who has applied for a position, and not got it, or some man who has been discharged for cause and wishes to wreak his vengeance upon somebody else, some merely irresponsible person, may launch into motion that which will place difficulties in the way of these places in my own riding, and of the two countries at large. Is that a rational thing to put on the statute-book ? Until I have had time to consider the question further, I think not. I think the Bill now on the statute-book is a more reasonable one and ought to commend itself to the members of this House. The existing law says :
For every violation of the provisions of section 1 of this Act the person, partnership, company or corporation violating it .	.	. shall
forfeit and pay the sum of $1,000, which may he sued for and recovered by Her Majesty's Attorney General of Canada, or the person duly authorized thereto by him.
Now, is it not a matter of sufficient importance, before an action of this kind is set on foot, that some person of reputation and standing should have the facts laid before him, in order that he may determine whether it is a proper case, in dealing with these difficult questions, to set the law in motion ? I submit to this House, very respectfully, that it is, and that to say that any person, however irresponsible, for whatever cause or motive, can be able, by merely laying information before a couple of justices of the peace, to set the law in motion, is placing a power in his hands which we ought not to do without considering it fully. Therefore, while most anxious to protect the rights of the working man in every practical way, I would urge upon this House that, in a matter of this importance, there can not possibly be a more reasonable thing than the sugges-

tion of the Prime Minister that the matter shall be left over for a week, sent to the committee, and carefully considered before we place this amendment upon the statute-book.

I quite agree with a part of the careful and deliberate speech of the hon. gentleman (Mr. Sutherland, Essex), who has just taken his seat. I too think this is a matter which we should approach with due deliberation, and that the House should take sufficient time to consider the case in all its aspects, so as to enact such a measure as will redound to the benefit of the class mainly to be affected, and incidentally to the benefit of the whole Dominion. But, that being the case, is it not all the more incumbent upon this House to get to work now 1 It is understood that this will probably be a short session. Should we not, without delay, and without regard to any political bias or any question except the best interest of the country, consider what we should do to assert ourselves fairly and squarely before the people we represent, and before the people of the United States, as to how we shall protect ourselves within the limits of the constitution ?
Now, we are not at the threshold of this matter. The principle has been affirmed, the Act has been passed, and we are now taking stock to see exactly where we stand. The hon. gentleman who has just taken his seat has told us, if I understood him aright, that every time this matter has come up in the House difficulties arise over at the border. If that is the case the proper time to consider it was when the hon. member for South Essex (Mr. Cowan) introduced his Bill. Now, I submit to the House this proposition, that the Act passed a few years ago was either right or wrong. If it is right, keep it and enforce it like men; if it is wrong, then repeal it and be done with it. But instead of that, we are met with a plea for delay, we are met with the persuasive words of some hon. gentlemen, some of them almost get down on their knees and beg of us to be very careful, to go very cautiously in this matter. We have been very considerate so far, and I must say that it is no credit to Canada that a law should be put upon our statute-book and allowed to remain a dead letter. Britons have always been able to hold their own. I do not say this in any aggressive spirit whatever, but I say it because, if it is right for the United States to have a law upon their statute-books to protect their labourers, it is right for us to have a law on our statute-books to protect our labourers. Our labourers are as good, are as honest, are as able man for man, as are the labourers of the United States, and we should be just as ready to protect them as the United States are ready to protect theirs.
I want to call the attention of the House to the fact that there is a sturdy class of
men in this country who deserve protection at our hands, who deserve that their interests should be conserved by their representatives in parliament. Last night, through the effort of hon. gentlemen on this side of the House, we were able to protect the farmers of this Dominion, and I think we will be taking a wise step if tonight we improve this opportunity to pass another bit of legislation that would protect the labouring classes of this country as well. From what class do we draw some of our best soldiers-soldiers that we count upon to defend this country and to defend Britain ? Why, we draw them from the ranks of these same labouring men-it is to them we look to a large extent to protect us in the hour of need.
Now, I have great deference of course for any suggestions thrown out in such a nice way by the premier; and for the moment, inexperienced as I am, I was almost led away by his suggestions to leave the matter over for a little while longer. I have noticed, however, that lie makes that request of us pretty often. In the matter of the sugar-beet discussion, I understood that he would have been very glad to have it left over indefinitely, or for another season. If I understood him and the members of the government aright yesterday, when we were discussing the binder twine question
Order, the hon. gentleman is referring to a previous discussion.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
validity of tlieir Act they have not taken the people into their confidence, they have not told us that they have a doubt as to its validity. If they have, they should let the country know it. I understand that they profess to have an Act upon the statute-book, and to have officials for the purpose of enforcing it to some extent, but that they have not been enforcing it. The object of this amendment is to put this Act in the same position as other statutes, so that it can be enforced by the ordinary machinery employed for the administration of justice, so that we may have in every eounty, in every riding, in every municipality, at our own doors, and in our own courts, machinery by which we can enforce this Act instead of being obliged to appeal to the government to secure our rights.
Now, the other argument the hon. member for Selkirk advanced was one which I confess is the most extraordinary argument I ever heard. Of course, I have not had much parliamentary experience yet, and perhaps, after I have heard some more speeches from lion, gentlemen opposite 1 shall not be surprised at anything. But, I was very much surprised to hear that lion, gentleman say that we would have to collect all the American cases, refer them to a committee or something of that kind, consider them, jiass an opinion upon them, be governed by them, and after we have done all this, we, the representatives of the people of Canada, could then begin to act. That is a most extraordinary proposition. It may be right, it may be wrong ; but speaking for myself and the people whom I represent, I will never consent by my vote to such a course, never, never, never.
I just want to refer to the hon. member for Guysborough (Mr. Fraser). I understand he is out of the House, so I will hit him lightly, although I cannot perhaps hit him very hard in any case. He points out the great danger that we are in. It may be so, but I do not so understand the temper of the American people. I understand them as a kindred race with ourselves. I understand that they are fair-minded and that they will, instead of retaliating if we protect ourselves, begin to appreciate us and understand that we are a self-reliant people prepared to vindicate our rights. But, if there is danger, I am prepared to meet the danger. The hon. member for Guysborough gives us his illustration of children, and says that it seems something like a couple of school boys wanting to hit each other, that it is a ease of blow for blow. I am unable to follow his argument. It is a ' childish ' illustration, and association sometimes breeds things of that kind. I urge my view upon this House from no party feeling at all; I urge it because I believe hon. gentlemen on the government side ought to be as much interested as we are. I urge it because I understand, that, more than upon this side of tire House, it is the province of

the government to devise the best measures for meeting these questions as they arise. It is for them to be prepared to meet the varied wants of Canada or to give place to other men. If we pass this Bill we are just acting fairly and honestly by a large and deserving class of the community. We are doing what we pretended to do in 1897 when this Act was passed. We are no longer perpetrating a false pretense upon the country ; we no longer proclaim ourselves to the people of the United States as people who have not the courage of their convictions and are afraid to enforce that which they pretend to enact. I would do justice to our own people, and in doing justice we will never be visited with anything that will do us harm. I understand this to be a fair measure of protection ; and not because there are a great many of these men in my own riding, but, because it is fair to the whole Dominion of Canada, and for this reason I will support the measure introduced by my hon. friend.

Mr. Speaker, I cannot allow this matter to pass without entering my protest against the manner in which the Alien Labour law has been enforced since it was put upon the statute-book. My hon. friend the member for South Leeds (Mr. Taylor) has mentioned the case of Mr. White. Mr. White resided in my constituency and kept a store there for a number of years. He gave up his business and moved his family to Ogdensburg, but he was sent back again, as my hon. friend has stated, after he had secured a position in Ogdensburg. He complained to me as well as to my hon. friend. I told him there was no use, that nothing could be done, because, while the Alien Labour law was on the statute-book, it was an impossibility to make it work. In the town of Prescott we have a number of Americans ; they are coming there day after day and securing employment in that town. Canadians cannot go into Ogdensburg. I think this is most unfair, and after this one example no Canadians have sought employment in the bordering town. I notice that the Minister of Marine and Fisheries (Hon. Sir Louis Davies) was very indignant at my hon. friend the member for South Leeds when he stated that Mr. Clute had received $40 a day, and when he insinuated that it should be placed to the credit of the Alien Labour law. I suppose that was for legal services in the case of strikes or something of that kind, and that is the reason why the hon. minister objected to that item.

I did not object to the item. I was quite aware of the item existing and of the money having been paid. What I objected to was that the hon. member for South Leeds (Mr. Taylor), having before him the Auditor General's Report showing the exact amounts paid for the enforcement of the law, and
.FEBRUARY 28, 1901
having before him the Auditor General's Report showing, in so many words, that this money, paid to Mr. Clute, was not paid in connection with the Alien Labour law at all, but in connection, as the report said, and which he had right before his eyes, with the inquiry into the labour troubles in the British Columbia mines, should have suppressed that information and tried to mislead the younger members of this House who said that they desired to form an honest opinion upon the question.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES (Hon. Sir Louis Davies).

speechtext:
Well, I did not understand it in that way. The point I wish to make is, that I claim that every strike we have had in this Dominion has been on account of Americans coming over and taking the places of Canadians. I will give an instance. In Valleyfield the great strike was due to so many American spinners coming to that town, being employed and working up the strike that took place and caused so much trouble there. The same thing has taken place in British Columbia on account of the aliens there. Americans come in, cut down the price of labour and cause the strikes. I was very much amused at the hon. member for North Essex (Mr. Sutherland) giving us an account of the state of affairs as it existed in the town of Windsor. I just looked up ' Hansard' to see what the hon. member for South Essex (Mr. Cowan) said when he introduced his Bill in 1897. At that time, in his speech
ly declare that on the 11th day of January, A.D. 1897, I was on a M. C. R. train, travelling on a ticket purchased at Dutton station, where I took the train for Detroit. My baggage was examined, and the officer asked me my age, where my home was, and how much money I had. I gave him the information, and had about $8.50. He then asked me what X was going to Detroit for. I replied, to visit my uncle in Detroit, and gave him his address. I had some private letters in my valise. He opened them, and one was an answer to an application I had made for a situation several months before, stating they had no opening. And I was ordered back to Canada, and they refused to permit me to enter the United States. I had no contract with any person to enter into or engage in any employment in the United States, but was on my way to a friend's. I after crossed on another ferry and went to my friend's, and am to-day on my return to my home in Canada.
And I make this solemn declaration conscientiously believing it to be true, and knowing that it is of the same force and effect as if made under oath and by virtue of ' The Canada Evidence Act, 1893.'
Declared before me at the city of Windsor, in the county of Essex, this 19th day of January, A.D. 1897.

A Commissioner.
Then, again, there is another long letter which the hon. member for North Essex (Mr. Cowau) places on record witli regard to the case of Mr. D. Llewellyn Irvine, and the hon. gentleman (Mr. Cowan), in the course of his speech, makes this statement :
he said :
A short time ago I picked up the Windsor Record, and I found the following article :
' Another outrage was committed on a young Canadian this morning by Detroit customs officials.
' W. J. Sutherland, a young man of about twenty years, from Wallacetown, Elgin county, came through on the Michigan Central Railway this morning to visit his uncle, Mr. F. Offer, at Detroit.
' He was met on the other side by one of the immigration agents of the United States, and asked to explain himself. The young man said he was going to visit his uncle. This did not satisfy the officers, and they proceeded to overhaul his baggage and open his letters found in his valise. Among them was one received some time ago from a firm in Detroit to whom Mr. Sutherland had applied for a situation. The letter was a refusal. The officers then assumed that he was again looking for a situation, and, after the usual compliments to Canada and Canadians, the young man was fired back over the river.'
After reading that article, and being desirous of securing information on the subject, and the true circumstances of the case, I sought out the young man and took from him a declaration, which I will read to the House. It is as follows :-
Dominion of Canada,
County of Essex,
To wit :
In the matter of W. J. Sutherland and his return to Canada under order from American customs.	.
I, William J. Sutherland, of the hamlet of W'allacetown, in the county of Elgin, do solemn-
Coming, as I do, from a frontier city and a border county, representing, as I do, a constituency whose shores are washed by the international waters that divide both countries, I know whereof I speak when I say that constituents of mine have had indignities heaped upon them, their private correspondence searched, their breeches pockets gone through, as in the case of young Sutherland, to see what money they possessed, as if they were moral lepers or Chinese highbinders. I say that the initiation, the inauguration, the enforcement and the Perpetuation of that policy is an insult to the citizens of the country initiating and enforcing it.
That is from the hon. gentleman (Mr. Cowan) who resides in the same city of Windsor with the hon. member for North Essex (Mr. Sutherland). It is hard for me to understand how the hon. gentleman (Mi1. Sutherland) can make the statement he made to-night. It looks as if he does not know what is going on in his own city, and it is quite evident that he has nothing to do with the labouring classes, or that he does not take any interest in them. I feel, Sir, that I would not be doing my duty when a question of this kind comes before parliament if I did not strenuously urge upon the government to put the Canadian labour law in such shape that it may be workable, and that the labouring men can have a ease tested before the ordinary | tribunals of the country. Why, the gravest criminal case is first tried before a justice [DOT] of the peace. Is there any good reason

against the infractions of this law being tried before a justice of the peace with the right of appeal ? I believe that the government should not hesitate about giving our working classes a chance of enforcing this law with the least possible trouble and expense to them, so as to protect their interests.

The discussion has wandered a long way from the Bill before the House, and from the Alien Labour Act of 1897. The instances which have been cited to the House have no bearing upon the actual Act itself. If these occurrences are correctly stated, they simply show a highhanded proceeding on the part of the United States officials in reference to Canadians who have gone there, and no law which we could pass would in any way be applicable. The whole point of citing the case mentioned by the hou. member for South Essex (Mr. Cowan) ; the declaration of the man upon whom the indignity was cast, tends to prove the fact that he was not going over there in violation of the United States Act, but that, nevertheless, he was sent back. The grievance there is that instead of the United States offi cials enforcing their law, they went a long way outside of it. I am sure that the hon. member for Grenville (Mr. Reid) will not contend that the action of his constituent, Mr. White, of Prescott, who took some member of his family to Ogdensburg to work, was a violation of the Alien Labour Act of the United States.
The customs official made him return, family and all.

I am not disputing what the hon. gentleman says, but his own statement shows that Mr. White did not violate the American Alien Act, and if he did not, then the officials were wrong in interfering with him. The Bill introduced by the hon. member (Mr. Clare) does not profess to redress a grievance of that kind. Take the case of the students from Kingston who went to Alexandria Bay, with the very laudable and praiseworthy intention of earning money by acting as waiters at the summer hotel. It is not pretended that they were engaged in Kingston for that work, and the sending of them back was a highhanded act on the part of the United States official ; but this Bill does not touch that.
Might I ask the hon. gentleman (Mr. Britton) what all that shows ?
Let me answer that question by asking another. If these people were not in violation of the United States Act, how are we to remedy that, either by the present Act or by the Bill now proposed ?
I would suggest to the hon. gentleman (Mr. Britton) that these cases show the extreme vigilance exercised
by the United States officials to enforce their Alien Labour law.
It does not show an extreme vigilance to enforce the law, but it shows an extreme vigilance to go outside of the law.
And, therefore, we should do nothing ?
We should.
We should lie down.
We should stand up.
Well, stand up.
I am standing up, but we should not attempt to do anything that is contrary to the law ourselves. We should be careful not to do what we have no authority in law to do.
We are not doing what we have authority to do.
Stand up.
Shut up.
I do not pay much attention to the hon. gentleman from East Northumberland (Mr. Cochrane).
I was not referring to you. I was talking to that coon behind you.

I hope I can proceed without interruption. The first section of the Act which the hon. gentleman from Waterloo (Mr. Clare) does not desire to repeal has reference simply to the employment in the United States of persons who come over here to work, and he does not seek in any way to change that provision in our Act of 1897. The amending Bill only deals with the enforcing of the Act. A penalty can be enforced in any way ; but before anything can be recovered, for a violation of the law, we have to establish that there has been a violation of it. I do not say that there has not been a violation, or if there has, that we should not attempt to enforce it. We should enforce it if there has been a violation, because if there has been in the United States, as our hon. friends say, such extreme vigilance to enforce their law that they have gone beyond the law. then we, at least, ought to go the length of enforcing the law as we have it on the statute-book.
Hear, hear.

But I venture to say that if hon. gentlemen opposite cannot find better cases than those they have given tonight, there has been no violation of it. The cases given have not been violations of the law, and any attempt to enforce such cases as if they were violations of the law, would bring us into contempt, because we would necessarily fail.

The hon. gentleman seeks to amend the Act, in the first place, by reducing the penalty. I dare say that Is wise, because it would perhaps have the effect desired, of haying the Act enforced for the recovery of the penalty, as it is easier to collect $200 than $1,000, and there is no doubt that in some cases a large penalty is a disadvantage in the enforcement of a law. But when we come to the hon. gentleman's mode of recovering the penalty, we come to the principal objection, and I think the acting leader of the opposition admitted that. I do not know what else he could refer to when he said that the Bill as introduced, was not workable, but would have to be amended in committee.
I said there were certain details.
It is the details I am talking about.
Every Bill is like that.

'No, not every Bill. Some Bills are so nearly perfect at the beginning that everybody appreciates the fact. But this Is so imperfect, that I do not see what objection any one could have to delaying it for further consideration. The hon. gentleman seeks to amend the method of enforcing the Act by providing that instead of the Attorney General or somebody under him having charge of its enforcement, as at present, any one may go before two justices of the peace of the county into which such alien or foreigner is imported and lay the information ; and he also provides that the penalty may be recovered in the same manner as debts of like amount are now recovered in any competent court in Canada. Now, I do not pretend to speak as a lawyer, but simply as any one would speak who would read this section. I do not know but that it might be held that the last part of the section killed the first part, so far as the recovery of the penalty is concerned, and that the only way to recover it would be to bring an action in those courts where debts of that amount would be recoverable. Perhaps, in addition to going before two justices of the peace, a person could sue in the division court for an infraction of the Act which may have occurred in the United States. Any lawyer will see the difficulty of a position of that kind, and will see that this is an ill-considered measure as it stands at present, and is therefore one that ought to have a good deal of consideration given to it before it or anything like it becomes law.
Then, another point. The complaint of hon. gentlemen to-night has been as to the enforcement of the American labour law by the deportation of our people who have gone over there, and they ask that retaliatory measures be adopted by us in reference to Americans who come over here.
Now, what authority is there on the part of this government or any other individual in Canada to report an American who comes to Canada and does anything in violation of this Act ? That is provided for by another section of the Act, which the hon. gentleman does not propose to touch at all. Section 6 of the Act of 1897 provides for that, but he does not p ropose to repeal that. There is nothing in this Bill at all except that it reduces the penalty and provides another way of recovering it. The Bill does not touch the offence in any way.
Before I sit down I wish to say that I do not yield to any of the hon. gentlemen opposite, although they may parade so much every session their deep, devoted interest in the workingman, and their desire at ail times and places to protect him who is so much oppressed by this government and those who support it. I do not use any such arguments as that; but I do not yield to any hon. gentleman on either side of the House in my desire to do what is right by those men ; and where the law has been violated I think the law ought to be enforced. But I am satisfied that there has been, from the time this law was passed, an honest desire on the part of the government to enforce it, but in such a way that international relations might not be strained. There is no use of making a fuss where there is no evidence to show that an offence has been committed. Yon ought not to try to make international trouble by taking up cases such as those that have been talked about from time to time, like the case of Mr. White who went to Ogdensburg, and the case of those students. But where there has been a clear violation of the law it ought to be applied, and I believe that the persons whom this government have employed from time to time to enforce the Alien Labour Act, if they had found a case which they had evidence to support, would have prosecuted it and obtained justice.

I do not rise, Mr. Speaker, to discuss the merits of an Alien Labour law. It is sufficient for me that I find such a law on the statute-book of this Dominion, and I assume, as I think every member of this House has a right to assume, that that law being there, was put there with a purpose and an object. It is of no use, I think, for the hon. member for Selkirk (Mr. McCreary) to tell us that the statute law of the United States is almost as bad as ours. If that means anything it means that our law wants improving, and I think the hon. member for South Waterloo (Mr. Clare) is making an effort to improve it. If I had any doubt upon the merits of the Bill which we are discussing, I think that doubt would have been removed by the language which I find in ' Hansard,' uttered by the right hon. gentleman who leads this House, when addressing the House in regard to the



particular statute which the hon. member for South Waterloo now seeks to amend. At page 658 of ' Hansard ' of 1897, the right hon. gentleman is reported as having used . these words with reference to it :
There cannot be any doubt as to the position of the government upon this Bill. In fact, I do not know, that it is at all advisable to prolong the debate any longer, because, so far as I can interpret the sentiment of the House, there is a unanimous feeling at this moment, whatever raay have been the opinions held by members in the past, that the persistence of the American Congress in keeping upon the statute-book these very obnoxious clauses, leaves no alternative to the Canadian people but to apply the same law themselves. The course adopted by our neighbours seems to leave no option to us but to apply to them the same measure of justice or injustice as they apply to us.
I would like to know if, in the last four years during which this statute has been upon our statute-books, any attempt has been made on the part of the Dominion to apply to the citizens of the United States, the same law that they apply to us.
Give au instance of any demand on our government to that effect.

I will tell the hon. gentleman in a moment what I have to say upon this subject. I am not here to he cross-examined by him. I assume, when I find a statute upon the books of this Dominion, that it was put there for a particular purpose, and it seems to me that the only purpose for which this statute could have been enacted was the protection of Canadian workingmen. The hon. member for Kingston (Mr. Britton) has argued that there is nothing to be done under this statute. Well, after what the right hon. the leader of the government said in 1897, as to the necessity. for this law, I do not think it is necessary for me to say anything In reply to the hon. gentleman. But, I ask if there are no cases to which this statute can he applied, what harm can there be in our complying with the request of the hon. member for South Waterloo, by striking out of the statute the string that has prevented its enforcement during the last four years ? On the other hand, if there are cases to which this law may he applied, surely in common justice to the workingmen, in whom the hon. member for .Kingston seems to take such particular interest, we should amend it in such a way as to enable it to be enforced. I do not want to take up time discussing the merits of a question that has been fully discussed and determined by a previous parliament. The statute is there, and it is the duty of the government either to see that it is enforced or else remove it from the statute-books altogether. Are these hon. gentlemen prepared to say that the law is not only inoperative and a nulity, but of no use ? If so, let them introduce a Bill to wipe it out. But, so long as it remains, it is evidence that necessity exists Mr. BARKER.
to protect our workingmen, and it should be made workable.
As to the particular section objected to, section No. 8, the insertion of such a clause in a law of this kind-a clause leaving the enforcement of the law completely in the hands of the Attorney General-seems to me an utter absurdity. Let us suppose an alien labourer infringes this Act when entering this Dominion at Halifax or Vancouver. Under the present statute no action can be taken against him at either of these places, but the complainant must come or write or telegraph to Ottawa and ask the Attorney General of the Dominion to investigate the case and for permission to prosecute the offender, and if the right hon. the leader of the government thinks as he did in 1897, he should favour the amending of the statute so as to make it really effective.

The hon. gentleman who has just taken his seat quoted the remarks made by the right lion, the First Minister in 1897, and rather tried to leave the impression on the House that the First Minister had not carried out the promise he then made. Well, I happened to be ou the committee to which was referred the Alien Labour Bill of that session, and which reported to the House. That committee acted on the promise made by the right hon. the First Minister in the remarks which my hon. friend has quoted. We took the Alien Labour law of the United States and copied it verbatim, ^and the Bill we reported to the House, and which passed is an exact copy of that law.
speakername: The MINISTER OP MARINE AND FISHERIES (lion. Sir Louis Davies).

speechtext: Did the United States tie up their Acts as you did yours ?

The clause to which the hon. gentleman refers was introduced by us because this was not a domestic measure alone, but an international measure, and it was deemed desirable and proper that the government should take the responsibility of enforcing the law in a matter that affected our international relations. I shall not discuss that point now as the First Minister lias intimated that the matter will come up when the government policy is announced.
There has been a great deal of talking to the galleries to-night. The hon. member for South Leeds (Mr. Taylor) has sought to impress upon the new members of the House the idea that he is really in earnest, and is advocating the passage of such a law in the interest of the workingmen rather than of the party to which he belongs. That may deceive some of the new members, but not any one who has been here the last ten or twelve years. Why ? Because we know such is not the object of the hon. gentleman. I remember well ills introducing a Bill of this kind every session for years when his own party was in power,

but never attempting to pass it into law. He made a great flourish about introducing an Alien Labour law, but when the leader of his party told him to subside he quietly withdrew the Bill. This farce he regularly went through every session for years.
When my right lion, friend came into oflice, he said that inasmuch as an Alien Labour law seemed to be desired by a portion of the community, because our cousins to the south had one in their statute-book, he would advocate our adopting one in identically the same terms. But the committee to which the matter was referred thought that, inasmuch as it affected our international relations with the United States, it was desirable that the responsibility of taking action should be upon the government, and that the government should initiate any prosecutions under the Act. I am not yet convinced that it is desirable to hand these prosecutions over to any man in the community who may choose to initiate proceedings. I think there is considerable force in the argument made use of by my hon. friend from Kingston (Mr. Britton), who pointed out that to allow, for instance, a dismissed employee to prosecute the company which dismissed him, without any responsibility whatever, would be going very far.
I merely rise to point out to my hon. friend this fact, that the Bill introduced by the hon. member for Waterloo is one which, I venture to say, not a legal gentleman on the other side will assert can be carried out in its present shape. I do not know what it means, and I would like to know if anybody can tell me what it means. I know the hon. gentleman's object, but it is not expressed in the Bill. But the law at present is clear and definite and capable of being enforced, and I have not heard it stated that the Attorney General has refused to prosecute in any case brought before him. I heard the hon. member for Grenville say that there were some breaches of the law in his constituency. Did he ever bring them before the Attorney General, and ask him to prosecute these Americans who had come to Prescott ? Does he desire that they should be prosecuted and driven out of the town ? I ask him, did he lay an information before the Attorney General, and ask him to prosecute ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: When this matter was brought before the hon. gentleman (Hon. Sir Louis Davies) as minister of the Crown was it not his duty, and the duty of the government, and the duty of the Attorney General of the Dominion to take action ? It was brought up by the hon. member for Leeds, and the record given.

My hon. friend (Mr. Reid, South Grenville) complained that there were some instances within his knowledge where the law was not enforced. I understood him to say that there were a number of 224
Americans in Prescott in violation of this law.	[DOT]
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: So there are.
Are they there against the wish of the hon. gentleman ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Yes.
Has the hon. gentleman reported the fact to the Attorney General of Canada, that prosecution may take place ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: No.
How is the Attorney General to know of the case then ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I did not report the cases, because other cases have been brought before the Attorney General and no prosecution has followed.
Will the hon. gentleman name a case.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I have read a case.

Will the hon. gentleman, on his responsibility as a member of this House, name one case and let it go on record in ' Hansard' ? So far as I know, the Attorney General has prosecuted all cases that were brought before him where there was sufficient evidence.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: How many prosecutions have there been ?

That has nothing to do with it. The law may not have been violated, the law is sufficient as it stands, and the Attorney General has not been neglectful of his duty. And I have merely been pointing out that the hon. member for South Grenville (Mr. Reid) who stated, in a casual way, that the law was being violated at Prescott admits that he has never brought the case to the notice of the Attorney General.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Was a case ever brought before the Attorney General, to the knowledge of the hon. gentleman, since this became law ?
I do not know. I do not recall a case in the maritime provinces that has ever been reported.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Then, the hon. minister is in the same position as I am. I would like to ask him if he could name a case where the government has taken action ?

As I am informed, the Attorney General has taken action in every case where the facts have been represented to him. But it appears that those who make an outcry in this House do not desire to enforce the law. One hon. gentleman took half an hour inveighing against the government because certain people are in his constituency in violation of the law. But when I asked him : Did you give that information to the Attorney General to be made the basis of a prosecution ? he says : No, I never did. How is the law to be put in force if hon. gentlemen like this who know that it is being violated secrete that information ? There is no difficulty about the law. But it is like other laws, for instance, the Scott Act. It will not enforce itself. Hon. gentlemen opposite will not enforce it or lend themselves to the enforcement of it, but will play to the galleries and make out that the law is not being enforced. My hon. friend (Mr. Clare) who introduced the Bill, has been met in a very proper way by the leader of the House. And I am glad to say also that he met the leader in a frank and straightforward way and said : I accept fully and frankly the statement of the leader of the House and I am well satisfied. The government asked to lay the matter over for a week, when they will be ready to announce what course they will take, and the promoter of the Bill is perfectly satisfied. But the politicians, who have been playing with this question for political purposes for the last ten or twelve years-at the head of whom is the hon. member for Leeds-are not satisfied ; and they have wasted the whole night talking about the enforcement of this Bill which the promoter knows, cannot be passed in the way in which it is introduced-it is not English and not law, and no lawyer would seek to put it upon the statute-book until it was revised and corrected.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Must not a man who is not a lawyer draft the Bill for this House ?

I do not understand the relevancy of the question, it does not require a man to be a lawyer to draft a Bill. Sometimes laymen draft Bills better than lawyers do, and write, better English. What I am saying is that if we do proceed with this Bill, let us make that Bill-
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Unworkable.
Hear, hear.

I am willing to accept that as the official announcement by the party opposite. There is no man better qualified to speak for his party than my hon. friend (Mr. Cochrane) ; and on reading the Bill, it seems to me that it is drawn up just to carry out his idea.	[DOT]
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I would like to ask the hon. minister a question, if he has no objection.
None whatever.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: There is this Bill and a similar one standing in the name of the hon. member for Vancouver (Mr. Smith). We have discussed this question since eight o'clock, that is for two hours and a half. In this measure is there anything contrary to the principle of these two Bills. Because, if there is nothing of that kind, then, after two hours and a half of discussion, should we not decide to either adopt or reject the principle of the Bill ? Because, at this stage, we are not dealing with the details but with the principle of the measure.

As it happened, the right hon. Prime Minister did not announce the introduction of a measure. He said that there were several Bills on the paper and that the government wished to consider the matter as one that had engaged their attention, and said that the conclusion reached would be announced on Wednesday next when the Bill came up again.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I think that hon. members on both sides will agree with me that it is deeply to be regretted that, when a question of such vital importance to the working people of this country is under consideration, we had not the presence of the Minister of Labour (Hon. Mr. Muloek) to assist in our deliberations. I am glad, however, that before the discussion closes, we may have the advantage and pleasure of hearing what he has to say upon this important matter. I think hon. members will agree with me, too, when I say that the hon. member for South Waterloo (Mr. Clare) has placed the working classes of the Dominion under lasting obligations to him. The workingmen in his own constituency are espepially under obligation to him because of the frank, manly statement he made in moving the second reading of his Bill this evening. The hon. gentleman is a self-made man, he has grown up from the ranks, a man who, by his indomitable industry, by his integrity, by his great ability, has achieved the honourable position which he occupies as one of the largest, one of the most progressive manufacturers in Ontario west. And when a gentleman who knows the wants, the requirements, the wishes of the working classes of this country as well as he does, takes the trouble at the earliest opportunity to rectify an Act which has been found to be unworkable, which has been upon the statutes of this country for nearly four years, and which has been practically a dead letter, he is entitled to the sympathy and the support of hon. gentlemen on both sides of the House. It is

not fair to meet him with that carping criticism to which he has been subjected to-night. If there are some minor defects in the amendments which he proposes to make to the Alien Labour Act, those defects could have been remedied in committee. But until the hon. gentleman gave notice of his intention to introduce this Bill, no other hon. member of this House had given any intimation of an intention to amend the Alien Labour law and make it workable, and it is only this evening that we are informed for the first time by the premier that the government are considering this matter, and may possibly bring down a measure amending the present unworkable law. Why, Mr. Speaker, statements have been made across the floor of the House for the past four years that the government have been considering this matter ; but I think I am within the judgment of the House in saying that the consideration which the government has been giving to this matter has for its object how to avoid their plain duty in the matter of enforcing an Act which was intended to be of some benefit to the people in whose interests it was passed. The hon. member for Hamilton read a statement made by the premier some three or four years ago when the hon. member for South Leeds (Mr. Taylor) proposed to introduce his Bill. I need not repeat the statement made by the premier on that occasion, but taking those words at their plain meaning, there is no hon. member in this House but will confess that they lead to the conviction that the intention of the government at that time was to put a workable measure upon the statute-book and to enforce it up to the hilt, as the United States authorities have persistently enforced their measure up to the hilt from 1897 to the present time.
Sir, I was amused, if that is a parliamentary expression, to hear the statement in the House to-night that the American Alien Labour law is not a workable measure. What appropriations have Congress made year after year for the enforcement of that law ? What reports have been made by the Alien Labour law commissioner as to the success which has attended his efforts in the enforcement of that law ? What figures has he given as to the number of men who have been deported, sent back from the frontier ? This information can all be obtained in the library, or from the authorities at Washington, by any hon. gentleman on the opposite side of the House, and if they take the trouble to look for that information they will find that every year a large appropriation has been made by the United States authorities for the enforcement of that law, and that every year that law has been vigorously enforced. It is only within the past two or three weeks that a statement has appeared in the press as to the action taken at Buffalo with regard to the deportation of Canadian workmen who were engaged in repairing one of the international bridges. So vigilant were the Alien Labour law officers of the United States that they actually deported these men who had been employed along with American workmen in repairing that bridge from the Canadian to the United States side of the river. Sir, the conduct and action of the United States Alien Labour law commissioner are in striking contrast with the conduct of the so-called la,bour commissioners that have been appointed from year to year to enforce the Alien Labour law here. American workmen were permitted to come over to the Canadian side of the river and assist in repairs on the Canadian side of that bridge, but when the repairs were completed on this side, and when it was necessary that Canadian workmen along with the Americans should go to the United States side of the bridge, they were deported, they were prohibited from going on with their work, they were sent back by the Alien Labour law commissioner ; and he proved by that act alone the Alien Labour law of the United States was capable of being enforced and was being enforced every day in the year. I have in my hand here a statement from the annual report of the secretary of the Treasury of the United States, and in speaking with regard to immigration and the number of people deported, he says :
In addition to the foregoing, there were excluded at the Mexican and Canadian borders a total of 1,616 aliens.
We will be told by and by that the great majority of them were sent back from the Mexican border, we will not be given information as to how many were sent back from the Canadian border, prohibited from entering the United States. I find further on in the same report:
Co-operation with organized labour in this country has been found useful in detecting violations of the contract labour law.
Instead of ridiculing the idea of invoking the aid and assurance of the workingmen to enable them to enforce the Alien Labour law, as was done by the Minister of Marine and Fisheries and others to-night, the Alien Labour law commissioners of the United States solicited the assistance and co-operation of the officers of the organized unions on the other side to assist them in enforcing that law.

The hon. gentleman is entirely wrong in imputing such a motive to me, I used no such language. I did not ridicule the aid of the workingmen ; on the contrary, I stated explicitly that whenever information had been given to the Attorney General of a breach of the law, he had given instructions to enforce it.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
Why, Mr. Speaker, the echoes of the voice of the Minister of Marine and Fisheries have hardly died away in this Chamber, he said only a few minutes ago that to allow an employee to prosecute a company from which he had been dismissed, and to take action against it would have been outrageous, and still he challenges the accuracy of the statement that I have just made. The minister will find out that the statement he made a few minutes afterwards, that we had wasted the time of the House in discussing this matter, is not a statement that will he accepted by the workingmen of the country, who asked the hon. gentlemen opposite three or four years ago for fair-play, and have got hut scant and cold justice from them up to the present time. We have another statement here from the annual report of the Treasurer of the United States. He says :
For the enforcement of the alien contract labour laws there was expended during the year

That is during the year ending June 30, 1900.
-the sum of $99,598.51, leaving a balance of the annual appropriation of $401.49.
$100,000 had been appropriated by the Congress of the United States for the enforcement of the Alien Labour law, and the commissioners were so active and diligent that they expended every dollar of that amount, less $400.
Will the hon. gentleman allow me to explain that that $100,000 voted by Congress is not only for the enforcement of the Alien Labour law, but also of the pauper immigration laws of the United States.

The hon. gentleman will have to go to the library and get these books, they are as available for him as for myself, and lest he should not understand, I will read again the statement that I have just read :
For the enforcement of the alien contract la-hour laws there was expended during the year the sum of $99,598.51, leaving a balance of the annual appropriation of $401.49.
I am giving the House the information contained in the annual report of the secretary of the Treasury of the United States. If the hon. gentleman wants further information I would advise him to refer to that gentleman, or to the Alien Labour law commissioner of the United States. I am not an authority on this matter, I prefer to quote the gentleman who occupies the distinguished position of the secretary of the Treasury of the United States.
Sir, the Minister of Marine and Fisheries let some further light into the reasons, or gave some further information of the reasons which caused the government to Sir LOUIS DAVIES.
insert clause 8 in the Bill passed in 1897. He says that this was an international matter, that they had to proceed very carefully, that therefore every safeguard had to be thrown about the Bill so that it would work no prejudice to the amicable international relations existing between the two countries. Now, Sir, I do not doubt but that may have been in the mind of the Minister of Marine and Fisheries at that time, and that was the reason why clause 8 was inserted in this Bill. But may I ask the permission of the House to give the reasons of one of his colleagues as to why this Bill was framed and passed in the shape in which we find it ? Am I within my rights in quoting from a statement made by the colleague of the hon. Minister of Marine and Fisheries, the Secretary of State, as to what his opinion of this measure was, and what he thought the prospects were of the enforcement of this Act after it was passed ? If so, I would like to read a few sentences from a statement which the hon. the Secretary of State made in another place :
I do not think the Act is likely to be enforced, and when it is not enforced it is a pity to place it on the statute-books, because it is not on a line with the views of the people of Canada. I should be sorry to see it on the statute-books because I know it would be an idle Act.
That is the opinion of the Secretary of State. He told another branch of the legislature of this country that it was not the intention to enforce the Act, that it would be an idle Act, and that it should not, for these reasons, be placed upon the statute-books. What does the hon. gentleman say to that explanation ? The hon. Secretary of State goes on further to deal with this very clause 8 that the hon. gentleman has discussed and explained at such great length. He says :
Under this Act persons can come in by thousands, and it is only when a report is sent to the Attorney General, and he makes inquiry that any action will be taken, and of course the party would by that time be absorbed in the community, and that would be an end of it. It is something we do not propose to carry out.
Now, I need not proceed any further to show he marked divergence of opinion that existed between the hon. gentlemen themselves in regard to this measure. Whether the intention of the government was as the hon. Minister of Marine and Fisheries has stated it, and I am bound to accept his explanation, or whether the hon. Secretary of State was speaking wide of the mark in the remarks which he made upon this measure, the hon. gentleman in the other Chamber was the better prophet of the two. The Act has been a dead letter, no honest attempt has been made to enforce it from the time it was put on the statute-book up to about six weeks before November 7 last, when the elections were held. Then, a little spurt was made, then a little flash in the

6S6
pail was seen, and lion, gentlemen opposite endeavoured to persuade the workingmen of Ontario that they were honest in their determination to enforce this Act. But, the workingmen of Ontario have had experience of these lion, gentlemen, and when the opportunity was afforded them in November of expressing their opinion upon the conduct of the government, they had not the slight est hesitation in expressing that opinion. But, the hon. Minister of Marine and Fisheries asks : Has any case been brought before the attention of the hon. Minister of Justice, and has he refused to prosecute upon any occasion when the facts were laid before him ? If the hon. gentleman wants any information upon this subject let me quote to him the letter written by the hon. Minister of Justice in reply to an appeal made to that hon. gentleman by the mayor of the city of Hamilton, the mayor of the city of which my hon. friend (Mr. Barker) sitting behind me. is one ot the worthy representatives. This is what the hon. gentleman's colleague said :
Ottawa, May 27, 1899.
J. V. Teetzel, Mayor, Hamilton, Ont.:
The Attorney General is not at liberty to give his assent to the prosecution for the infraction of the Alien Labour 'law to which you refer, au understanding having been reached last summer by the international commissioners that the Alien Labour law, until the negotiations were concluded, should remain in abeyance in Canada in respect to persons coming from the United States and in the United States in respect to persons going thither from Canada. Until it is shown that this understanding is not observed by the United States officers, no action can be taken here.

Is that sufficient answer to the hon. Minister of Marine and Fisheries to show that, there is a case where the hon. Minister of Justice was invited to do justice to the operatives of the city of Hamilton, and that he refused to allow any action to be taken- V
That.was perfectly right.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
The right hon. leader of the government (Sir Wilfrid Laurier), or no member of the government, has yet been frank enough to take the House into his confidence and tell us when the understanding so reached between the Canadian and American commissioners came to an end. We have a right to know, if such an agreement did exist, when it was abrogated, and what were the causes of its abrogation, and if the abrogation of that agreement is the cause of an appropriation of $9,000 being asked in the estimates for the enforcement of the Alien Labour law during the coming year. We have had no information of that kind vouchsafed to us. but we have had statements made again and again, and oft repeated by the alien labour commissioner at Buffalo and the collector of customs at Port Huron, that so far
as they knew there was no arrangement or understanding made for the non-enforcement of the United States Alien Labour law, but that, on the contrary, at all times and under all circumstances, the law has been vigorously enforced. This is the answer made to the allegations which we have heard again and again, but is it a sufficient reason why the Canadian Alien Labour law was not enforced ? I do not think 1 shall take up any more of the time of the House discussing this matter, because it seems to me that the proposition of my hon. friend (Mr. Clare), coming from a gentleman of his experience, coming from a gentleman who is a large employer of labour, is such a reasonable proposition, is such a conservative proposition, is such a just proposition. that it should not have been treated as the right hon. Prime Minister (Sir Wilfrid Laurier) proposes to treat it, of being shelved for a week or ten days. The hon. gentleman has given great attention to this matter, he has seen the disabilities under which his own and other workmen labour by the non-enforcement of this Alien Labour law, he has seen that strikes have been engendered. that bad feeling has been fostered because of the facilities which have been given through the non-enforcement of this law to employers of labour on this side of the line when they had a disagreement with their operatives to bring American operatives from the other side without let or hindrance to take their places. It has caused a great deal of bitterness between employers" and their employees. If there had been an honest, straightforward enforcement of the law the disputes which take place from time to time between employers and employees would have been settled in a more amicable and satisfactory way, and the friction which has resulted would not have ensued. I hope that the proposition of my hon. friend, so fair and so reasonable, will be accepted by the ma jority in this House, and that at the earliest possible moment the Alien Labour law will be put into a workable condition and will be enforced fairly and reasonably from one end of this Dominion to the other. The workmen of this country have a right to that measure of justice and protection from the government. Sneers were made by an hon. gentleman opposite at my hon. friend from South Leeds (Mr. Taylor) because he had not been successful from year to year in securing the passage of an alien labour law by the House of Commons. Sir, whatever credit is due for the passage of a measure of that kind cannot be wrested from the hon. member for South Leeds. Year in and year out he 'persisted, whether his friends were in office or whether his opponents were in office, in introducing this measure for the protection of Canadian workmen into the parliament of Canada. He drew public attention to the matter, he aroused and cultivated public opinion as to

tlie necessity of a measure of that kind, and if he was not suceesful up to the year 1896, it was not his fault. The hon. gentleman opposite who has sneered at him tonight must share the responsibility of that failure, because neither that hon. gentleman nor any of his supporters, from the first time my hon. friend introduced his measure in 1890, or 1891, up to 1896, uttered one word in favour of a motion of that kind, or in favour of the adoption of the Bill which my hon. friend placed before the parliament of Canada.
The hon. gentleman (Mr. Taylor) withdrew his Bill.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The man who insisted upon forcing that measure upon the attention of the people got little or no support from hon. gentlemen opposite. If they had been as anxious before 1896 as they were professedly since then, to do justice to the workingmen, they would have given the hon. member for South Leeds their assistance and co-operation in providing a law that would be workable, instead of one that is practically a dead letter. I hope that this measure will be passed to its second reading to-night, that the House will resolve itself into Committee of the Whole, that any imperfections that may be found will be struck out, and that it will be improved, with the assistance of the hon. Minister of Marine and Fisheries and of the hon. Minister of Labour (Mr. Mulock). We look to the hon. Minister of Labour, as a matter of course, to come to the assistance of the workingmen in perfecting this measure. With the assistance of these two ministers, and with the assistance of other hon. gentlemen, we will have a measure that will be of some advantage to the workingmen of the country, and they will appreciate the action of parliament if it completes tint work to-night.

It is to me somewhat amusing to hear hon. gentlemen opposite prate so loudly and so long in the interests of the labouring men of this country, when for eighteen years they supported a government which absolutely and positively refused to pass an Alien Labour law in Canada. The hon. gentleman (Mr. Clarke) says that if the Liberal party, when in opposition, had supported the hon. gentleman for Leeds (Mr. Taylor) in his proposal yearly brought up in the House, that possibly the government of that day might have been forced to enact an Alien Labour law. The hon. gentleman (Mr. Clarke) desires to take his policy from the Liberal party. He is getting his policy from the Liberal party now: he will get it from the Liberal party fcr many years to come.
Oh. no.
Sir, there have been several statements made to the House to-

night, as to whether or not the Attorney General of Canada has ever enforced the Alien Labour law since it was placed upon the statute-book. I am inclined to think that if hon. gentlemen opposite had more fully desired the actual enforcement of that law, rather than desiring to make political capital against the government, it would be found that the Alien Labour law would be enforced every time they sought to enforce it. I venture to say that the hon. gentleman from Toronto (Mr. Clarke) has never on one single occasion endeavoured to have the Alien Labour law enforced in this country. I ask him now, if he ever approached the Attorney General of Canada with the suggestion that the Alien Labour law should be enforced.

If the hon. gentleman desires an answer, I will give it to him. 1 have gone to the superior of the Minister of Justice; I have gone to the Prime Minister again and again from my place in this House, and I have appealed to him to have that Alien Labour law enforced.

The hon. gentleman (Mr. Clarke) cannot get out of it in that kind of way. The statute distinctly says that it shall be enforced on an application to the Attorney General of Canada, and not to the premier of Canada. I will venture to say that the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clarke) has never gone to the Attorney General, notwithstanding the redundancy of feeling which he tries to exhibit in the interest of the workingmen. He has a large number of them in West Toronto, and he endeavours to get their votes.
I am proud to say I get them.

Yes, he usually gets them. Now, Mr. Speaker, let me tell you that I have been more energetic in the interest of the constituency I have the honour to represent than has the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clarke), because I have seen that the law was enforced, and enforced promptly and effectively. We had in the town of Welland in which I live, contractors bringing Italians from the United States to do work on our public streets. I wired the Attorney General of Canada that the Alien Labour law was being violated, and I at once received a wire in reply authorizing me to see that the law was enforced, and in twelve hours from that time these men were deported from Canada.
Air. PUTTEE, Does the hon. gentleman wish us to understand that Italians were deported to the United States?
ill'. GERMAN. They certainly were. We have Italians in Canada who are Canadian subjects, and there are Italians in the United States who are American citizens, and these Italians who were American citizens and aliens had no right to come to

Canada and do work which Canadians could and would do, and they were deported immediately. The same thing happened along the shore of Lake Erie, where American citizens were building summer residences.
Would the hon. gentleman tell the House the date of that deportation ?
It was about May of last year; it was early in the spring of last year. The contractors were building a granolithic sidewalk in the town of Welland.
About the time you got your nomination.

No, sir; it was very much earlier than the time I got my nomination, and whether I had got my nomination or not I would try and see that the Alien Labour law was enforced, because I take a greater interest in the workingmen than do the hon. gentlemen opposite. These men prate of their Canadian loyalty in this House, but outside of this House they are meek and mild as lambs. The hon. gentleman from Toronto (Mr. Clarke) spoke about the work being done on the international bridge. I happen to know something about that. The International Bridge Company brought expert workmen from the United States; men that they could not get here, and there never was a complaint from any person in Canada. I challenge the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clarke) to say that any Canadian expert workman who worked on that bridge on the American side of the Niagara river was ever deported. I defy him to mention the name of one.
I say they were. 1 can tell my hon. friend (Mr. German) that I know they were.

Give us the names, if you please.
Mi-. LANCASTER. I have not the names here.

The hon. gentleman cannot mention the name of an expert workman from Canada working on the international bridge wdio was deported. Why, they have only begun to work on the American side of that bridge within the last mouth. This all shows that hon. gentlemen opposite in order to make a point if possible against the government, will endeavour to garble the facts. I happen to know that the international bridge has not been built to the international channel until the last month. It is not all completed yet. They have just begun at the drawbridge there lately. There has never been an expert Canadian w-ho worked on the international bridge deported even by Mr. DeBarry, who has been the most effective officer in the United States service so far as .
deporting aliens is concerned. The Canadian Alien Labour law is, with slight exceptions, a verbatim copy of the United States Alien Labour law. The greatest difficulty that has arisen hitherto in regard to the enforcement of the Canadian Alien Labour law has been by reason of the very active operations of Mr. DeBarry, of Buffalo. We do not hear any complaint about it between Detroit and Windsor. We do not hear any complaint about it between the town of Niagara Falls on the Canadian side, and the city of Niagara Falls on the American side. I have heard something to-night about Prescott. I know nothing about the St. Lawrence district, but I venture to say that east of British Columbia, Mr. DeBarry the United States official has created more difficulty in regard to the operation of the Alien Labour law than any other one man either in the United States or Canada, by reason of his very great industry. He appears to be supported by the labour unions in the city of Buffalo, and he has continually and deliberately violated the Alien Labour law of the United States. He has exceeded the duty imposed upon him by the law of the United States. I know that he has taken Canadians who have gone to the United States and sent them back, just as illegally as he would take me or any other hon. member of this House by the shoulder and send us back. He has done it in violation of the Act, by reason of the pressure brought to bear upon him by the labour unions of the city of Buffalo. However, it has been done, in the county I have the honour to represent, it has created a good deal of friction. It was used as a political influence against me in the last election. It was said that I was not doing my duty to the labouring men, although I showed the people that I had been doing my duty. My opponent endeavoured to convince the public that the government had not been doing its duty-that it had put a law on the statute-book, and had not been endeavouring to enforce it. So far as I am concerned, I desire to see the Alien Labour law of this country enforced, and enforced properly in the interest of the public.
There are cases when it is in the interest of the Canadian people themselves that aliens should be employed in this country. There are occasions when you cannot get in this country the labouring men to do the work which you want done. There are occasions arising continually when you need employees whom you cannot get here, and it is necessary to get them in another country. Consequently, we have to be exceedingly careful in placing a law on the statute-book which will affect the rights of the public, as an Alien Labour law will affect those rights if improperly drawn and improperly carried out.
I am inclined to think the law as it at present stands will bear amendment. I had intended to propose an amendment myself,

and I am not certain that before this session is over 1 shall not do so, except that I hear from the government to-night that they desire that these matters shall stand over for a time, as they contemplate proposing a policy which they think may be satisfactory to the House. I am willing to bide my time and see what the proposition of the government is. If they bring down a Bill which is satisfactory, I shall be prepared to support it. If they bring down a Bill which is not satisfactory, I will rise in my place and to the best of my ability endeavour to make it satisfactory, at any rate, to me and the people whom I have the honour to represent. There is one respect in which, I think, the Alien Labour law can very properly be amended. The law at present is that you cannot contract outside the country ; that
is,	you cannot bring into this country aliens under contract made outside of the country. Men attempt to violate that law by telling employees to come to Canada and they will employ them here. If that objection can be got over, the law as it stands is as perfect as any Alien Labour law you can have. We have officers throughout the country with intelligence to enforce the law. I think possibly it might be made a little more elastic than it is ; it probably will be ; but I can say that the Alien Labour law as it stands to-day on the statute-book has been effective. It has been enforced wherever any gentleman has endeavoured to enforce
it,	and it has been a great benefit to the people of the country wherever they desired to take the benefit of it. It can be improved, but without improvement it is exceedingly better than anything hon. gentlemen opposite ever gave to the people of this country.

Mr. Speaker, I will not yield to the hon. member for West Toronto (Mr. Clarke) in his zeal for the workingmen. I happened to have been, along with my hon. colleague, elected for the county of Cape Breton by a majority of the votes of the workingmen of that county ; and we were elected, Sir, because during the time we served in the local legislature of Nova Scotia, we put on the statute-book of that province a considerable amount of legislation for the benefit of the miners. We can, I think, claim it as some tribute to that legislation that when a few months ago 140,000 American miners went out on strike, they struck for the very same concessions from the capitalists which we in Nova Scotia had secured by statute, chiefly at the request of the workingmen themselves. So that I have some authority to speak for the workingmen in the constituency which I have the honour to represent.
Now, I cannot support this Bill, for two reasons. . In the first place, it will prohibit the importation of skilled labour from another country into this country, no matter how much we may require it. If the great Mr. GERMAN.
iron works in Cape Breton and the contemplated iron works at Sault Ste. Marie are not to be allowed to import alien labour, it will be impossible for us to get those great industries started in this country. Further, if the importation of such labour is prohibited, it will cut off the labour from the coal miners of this country and even the ordinary labourers, and diminish the market of the agriculturists. We have everything to lose by making an inflexible law on this question.
For one, I do not care to submit the interpretation of this law to the judgment of any two magistrates. I think we must recognize that only some man or body of men with a due sense of their responsibility can be properly entrusted with the enforcement of this Act. I know magistrates, numbers of them, who no doubt would put this Act into operation with prudence ; but we all know that there are scores of magistrates in almost every constituency who could not be trusted to adjudicate upon it with discretion and prudence.
I believe I am speaking in the interest of a great many thousands of workingmen in Cape Breton and the eastern part of Nova Scotia when I say that I oppose this Bill for the reasons I have given. At the same time, it may be possible before very long to introduce some machinery for the carrying out of this law without the difficulty of approaching the Minister of Labour or the Attorney General of Canada. But, for the reasons given, I cannot see my way clear to support the Bill.
